docs.title: After the Semester
docs.text: The semester is winding down—congratulations! This section helps you wrap up effectively and set yourself up for future success.

docs.title: In This Section
docs.text:
### End of Semester Checklist Wrap up tasks and deadlines

### Reflecting & Iterating Turn this semester's lessons into next semester's improvements

docs.title: Last Week of Classes
docs.text:
• Communicate final exam details
  • Provide study guidance and review materials
  • Complete any remaining grading from the semester
  • Send course evaluation reminders

docs.title: Finals Week
docs.text:
• Administer final exam
  • Hold extended office hours for questions
  • Begin final grading

docs.title: After Finals
docs.text:
• Complete all grading by the deadline
  • Submit grades through ConnectCarolina
  • Review course evaluations when available
  • Document what worked and what to change

docs.title: Key Deadlines
docs.text: Refer to the Registrar's Academic Calendar for official grade submission deadlines.

docs.title: End of Semester Checklist
docs.text: A comprehensive checklist to close out the semester smoothly and meet all deadlines.

docs.title: Final Exam Preparation
docs.text:
• [ ] Confirm final exam date, time, and location (check for room changes!)
  • [ ] Send detailed final exam announcement to students
  • [ ] Schedule accommodated testing with ARS
  • [ ] Hold review session or office hours
  • [ ] Finalize and print/prepare final exam

docs.title: Wrapping Up Content
docs.text:
• [ ] Complete any remaining course content
  • [ ] Tie course themes together
  • [ ] Preview how skills/knowledge will be useful going forward
  • [ ] Thank students for their engagement

docs.title: Course Evaluations
docs.text:
• [ ] Remind students to complete course evaluations
  • [ ] Consider giving class time for evaluation completion
  • [ ] Explain how you use feedback to improve

docs.title: Grading
docs.text:
• [ ] Clear out any remaining ungraded work
  • [ ] Grade final assignments and exams promptly
  • [ ] Calculate final grades according to syllabus
  • [ ] Double-check calculations, especially borderline cases
  • [ ] Document any grade adjustments or curving applied

docs.title: Office Hours
docs.text:
• [ ] Hold extended office hours during finals
  • [ ] Be available for last-minute questions
  • [ ] Prepare for student concerns about grades

docs.title: Grade Submission
docs.text:
Don't miss the deadline!

Grade submission deadlines are firm. Check the Academic Calendar for exact dates.

  • [ ] Review ConnectCarolina grade submission procedures
  • [ ] Submit grades by the deadline
  • [ ] Handle any incomplete (IN) grade contracts if needed
  • [ ] Verify grades were submitted successfully
  • [ ] Save records of your grade calculations

docs.title: Course Materials
docs.text:
• [ ] Archive your Canvas course (it will eventually become read-only)
  • [ ] Save copies of materials you may want to reuse or modify
  • [ ] Note any copyrighted materials that need updating next time
  • [ ] Back up any content not stored in Canvas

docs.title: Records Retention
docs.text:
• [ ] Save grade records securely
  • [ ] Retain exams and major assignments per department policy
  • [ ] Document any academic integrity cases and outcomes
  • [ ] Save any student work that may be used as examples (with permission)

docs.title: Quick Reflection
docs.text:
Before you step away, jot down quick notes while things are fresh:

  • What worked really well this semester?
  • What would you definitely change next time?
  • Were there any resources or tools you wish you'd had?
  • What surprised you about student learning this semester?

See Reflecting & Iterating for a deeper reflection framework.

docs.title: Related Resources
docs.text:
• ConnectCarolina Grading — Grade submission instructions
  • Grade Appeals Process — Handling grade disputes
  • Incomplete Grade Policy — When and how to assign an incomplete

docs.title: Reflecting & Iterating
docs.text:
The end of the semester is a valuable opportunity to reflect on what worked, what didn't, and how to improve for next time.

Timing matters

Do your reflection while the semester is still fresh—ideally within a week or two of grades being submitted.

docs.title: What Worked Well?
docs.text:
Take note of:

  • Activities that generated high engagement
  • Assignments that produced quality student work
  • Explanations or examples that really clicked
  • Policies that reduced friction
  • Tools that made your life easier

Keep what works

Don't overthink what's already working. Keep successful elements and iterate on the rest.

docs.title: What Was Challenging?
docs.text:
Identify:

  • Topics students consistently struggled with
  • Assignments with unclear instructions or poor outcomes
  • Points of confusion or frequent questions
  • Time management issues (yours or students')
  • Technology frustrations

docs.title: What Will You Change?
docs.text:
Prioritize:

  • High-impact changes that address real problems
  • Small tweaks that are easy to implement
  • Experiments you want to try
  • Things to research or learn more about

docs.title: Learning & Assessment
docs.text:
• Did students achieve the learning objectives you set?
  • Which assessments gave you useful information about student learning?
  • Were there any assessments that weren't worth the time invested?
  • Did the workload feel appropriate—for students and for you?

docs.title: Engagement & Classroom Climate
docs.text:
• How engaged were students during class sessions?
  • Did students participate in discussions and activities?
  • Did students seem to feel comfortable asking questions?
  • Were there students who seemed disengaged? What might have helped?

docs.title: Logistics & Systems
docs.text:
• Did your grading approach feel sustainable?
  • Were your communication patterns effective?
  • Did technology help or hinder the course?
  • Were your office hours well-utilized?

docs.title: Your Experience
docs.text:
• What energized you this semester?
  • What drained you?
  • What do you wish you had known at the start?
  • What would make next semester more sustainable?

docs.title: Using Course Evaluations
docs.text: Course evaluations become available after grades are submitted. Use them productively:

docs.title: Reading Evaluations
docs.text:
1. Read once for patterns, not individual comments
  2. Look for specific feedback, not just ratings
  3. Note what students valued, not just complaints
  4. Consider the context (required vs. elective, class size, etc.)

docs.title: Responding to Feedback
docs.text:
• Identify 1-2 actionable changes based on feedback
  • Don't try to fix everything at once
  • Remember: you can't please everyone, and that's okay
  • Consider sharing changes with future students ("Based on feedback, I've updated...")

docs.title: Course Design Essentials
docs.text:
Effective course design creates a coherent experience where learning objectives, activities, and assessments work together to help students succeed.

Coming Soon

This page is under development. Check back soon for comprehensive course design resources.

docs.title: Quick Principles
docs.text:
1. Start with the end in mind — What should students be able to do by the end of the course?
  2. Align everything — Ensure activities and assessments directly support your learning objectives
  3. Build in feedback loops — Give students opportunities to practice and receive feedback before high-stakes assessments
  4. Consider cognitive load — Break complex skills into manageable steps
  5. Plan for engagement — Include varied activities that actively involve students

docs.title: Semester Kickoff Checklist
docs.text:
A comprehensive checklist to ensure you're ready for the first day—and first week—of class. Use this as a reference each semester to make sure nothing falls through the cracks.

Pro tip

Bookmark this page! Many instructors return to this checklist semester after semester.

docs.title: Syllabus & Course Materials
docs.text:
• [ ] Update syllabus with current semester dates
  • [ ] Verify textbook information is current and available
  • [ ] Check that all linked resources (websites, articles) still work
  • [ ] Review and update office hours for the new semester
  • [ ] Update any policies based on last semester's lessons learned

docs.title: Canvas Setup
docs.text:
• [ ] Import or create your Canvas course shell
  • [ ] Update the course home page with current information
  • [ ] Set up your module structure for at least the first 2-3 weeks
  • [ ] Configure assignment groups and grading scheme
  • [ ] Set up the Gradebook with your weighting preferences
  • [ ] Create or import your syllabus page
  • [ ] Test the student view to see what students will experience

docs.title: Logistics
docs.text:
• [ ] Confirm classroom assignment and visit the room if unfamiliar
  • [ ] Test classroom technology (projector, microphone, document camera)
  • [ ] Request any additional technology needs from ITS
  • [ ] Review your roster for any students with ARS accommodations
  • [ ] Coordinate with TAs on responsibilities and meeting times

docs.title: Canvas Final Prep
docs.text:
• [ ] Publish your Canvas course (make it visible to students)
  • [ ] Schedule or send welcome announcement
  • [ ] Verify all first-week assignments are ready and published
  • [ ] Double-check due dates and availability windows

docs.title: Communication
docs.text:
• [ ] Send welcome email to students (Canvas announcement or email)
  • [ ] Share any pre-class preparation expectations
  • [ ] Provide information about required materials/textbooks
  • [ ] Include how to reach you with questions

docs.title: Personal Preparation
docs.text:
• [ ] Review your teaching notes for the first class
  • [ ] Prepare any icebreaker or first-day activities
  • [ ] Plan how you'll learn student names
  • [ ] Prepare a backup plan if technology fails

docs.title: Before Class
docs.text:
• [ ] Arrive early to test technology
  • [ ] Write your name and course info on the board/screen
  • [ ] Have your slides/materials ready
  • [ ] Bring a backup of key materials (USB drive, printouts)

docs.title: During Class
docs.text:
• [ ] Welcome students and introduce yourself
  • [ ] Review the syllabus highlights (not every word!)
  • [ ] Explain how to navigate Canvas and find resources
  • [ ] Share your communication preferences and response times
  • [ ] Give students something meaningful to do (not just "read the syllabus")
  • [ ] Start learning names—consider a name tent or brief introductions

docs.title: After Class
docs.text:
• [ ] Note any students who were absent (for later follow-up if needed)
  • [ ] Send a follow-up announcement summarizing key points
  • [ ] Review and adjust plans for the next class based on what you learned

docs.title: First Week of Class
docs.text:
• [ ] Post your first substantive content/assignment
  • [ ] Respond promptly to student questions to set expectations
  • [ ] Hold your first office hours (even if no one comes)
  • [ ] Check Canvas analytics to see who has and hasn't logged in
  • [ ] Follow up with students who haven't accessed the course
  • [ ] Touch base with your TAs about how the first week went
  • [ ] Make note of any adjustments needed for next time

docs.title: First Week Announcement Template
docs.text:
Use this as a starting point for your welcome message:

Welcome to [Course Name]!

I'm looking forward to working with you this semester. Here's what you 
need to know to get started:

**Before our first class:**
- Review the syllabus [link to syllabus page]
- Obtain the required textbook/materials [details]
- Complete the "Getting Started" module in Canvas [if applicable]

**Our first class:**
- Date, Time, Location
- Bring: [laptop, notebook, etc.]

**How to reach me:**
- Office hours: [days/times]
- Email: [your email]
- Response time: I typically respond within [24-48 hours]

Questions? Reply to this announcement or email me directly.

Looking forward to meeting you!
[Your name]

docs.title: Community
docs.text: The Teaching Toolkit is built by and for UNC instructors. This section is where we share collective wisdom and invite your contributions.

docs.title: Get Involved
docs.text:
### Share Your Tips Contribute your teaching wisdom

### Tips Collection Browse tips from colleagues

docs.title: Why Contribute?
docs.text:
The best teaching tips often come from the trenches—from instructors who've tried something, iterated on it, and discovered what actually works. Your contribution could help a colleague across campus save time, connect with students, or try something new.

We're especially interested in:

  • Time-saving techniques
  • Creative solutions to common problems
  • Tool recommendations and workflows
  • Strategies for engagement
  • What makes teaching sustainable and joyful

docs.title: Contributors
docs.text: Coming soon: a wall of appreciation for community contributors!

docs.title: Contact Us
docs.text:
Questions about the Teaching Toolkit? Suggestions? Just want to chat about teaching?

Email the CFE team

docs.title: Share Your Teaching Tips
docs.text: Have a teaching tip, technique, or tool that's made a difference in your courses? We'd love to hear about it—and share it with colleagues across campus.

docs.title: What We're Looking For
docs.text:
The best tips are:

  • Specific — Tell us exactly what you do, not just general principles
  • Actionable — Others should be able to try it themselves
  • Tested — You've used it and seen results
  • Honest — Including limitations or situations where it might not work

docs.title: Quick Tips
docs.text:
Short, actionable ideas that can be described in a few sentences.

Example: "I start every class with a one-question quiz on the previous session's material. It only takes 3 minutes, but it dramatically improved retention and attendance."

docs.title: Detailed Practices
docs.text:
Longer descriptions of teaching approaches with context and examples.

Example: A full description of how you structure group work, including how you form groups, what roles you assign, and how you debrief.

docs.title: Tool Recommendations
docs.text:
Technology or resources that have helped your teaching.

Example: "I use [tool] for [purpose]. Here's why it works for me and tips for getting started."

docs.title: Faculty Spotlight Interview
docs.text: If you'd be willing to be interviewed about your teaching for a Faculty Spotlight, let us know!

docs.title: Option 1: Quick Form
docs.text: Fill out our Google Form to submit a tip. (Takes about 5 minutes)

docs.title: Option 2: Email
docs.text:
Send your tip directly to cfe@unc.edu with:

  • Your tip or practice
  • Your name and department (or note if you prefer to remain anonymous)
  • Any relevant context or examples

docs.title: Option 3: GitHub
docs.text: Tech-savvy? Submit a pull request directly to our GitHub repository.

docs.title: What Happens Next
docs.text:
1. We review your submission for fit and clarity
  2. We might follow up with questions or requests for more detail
  3. We publish with appropriate attribution (or anonymously if you prefer)
  4. You help colleagues across campus!

docs.title: Attribution Options
docs.text:
When you submit, let us know how you'd like to be credited:

  • Full attribution: Name, title, and department
  • Partial attribution: Name and department only
  • Anonymous: No identifying information

docs.title: Recent Contributions
docs.text:
On announcements

"I started every announcement with a TL;DR line at the top and student engagement with announcements went up noticeably. They actually started replying with questions!"

— Professor in the School of Journalism

On office hours

"I moved my office hours to a campus coffee shop once a week. More students show up in that one hour than in all my regular office hours combined."

— Assistant Professor, History

docs.title: Questions?
docs.text: Not sure if your tip is right for the Toolkit? Just ask! Email cfe@unc.edu.

docs.title: Teaching Tips Collection
docs.text: Practical tips from UNC instructors across campus. Browse by category or search for specific topics.

docs.title: Communication & Announcements
docs.text:
TL;DR Format

"I started every announcement with a bold TL;DR line summarizing the key action item. Student engagement with announcements increased noticeably—they actually started reading them."

— Professor, School of Journalism

Consistent Timing

"I send my weekly announcement every Sunday at 5 PM. Students have told me they appreciate knowing exactly when to expect course information."

— Dr. Martinez, History Department

Subject Line Strategy

"My announcement subject lines always start with the week number and a verb: 'Week 5: Submit your draft by Friday.' It makes scanning the announcement list much easier for students."

— Instructor, Writing Program

docs.title: Office Hours
docs.text:
Coffee Shop Office Hours

"I moved my office hours to a campus coffee shop once a week. More students show up in that one hour than in all my regular office hours combined."

— Assistant Professor, History

Walk-In vs. Appointment

"I split my office hours: two hours of drop-in time and one hour of appointments. Students who are anxious about office hours feel more comfortable booking an appointment, while those who just have quick questions appreciate the flexibility."

— Associate Professor, Psychology

The First Visit

"I require all students to come to office hours once in the first three weeks—even just to say hi. After that initial visit, they come back much more readily when they actually need help."

— Senior Lecturer, Mathematics

docs.title: Engagement & Participation
docs.text:
Muddiest Point

"I end every class by asking students to write down their 'muddiest point'—the thing they're most confused about. It takes 2 minutes and tells me exactly what to address next time."

— Associate Professor, Biology

Think-Pair-Share Timing

"For think-pair-share, I'm very explicit with timing: 'You have 2 minutes to think on your own, then 3 minutes with a partner, then we'll share.' The structure helps students actually engage instead of immediately turning to their neighbor."

— Instructor, Philosophy

Name Cards

"I have students make name cards for their desks for the first few weeks. It helps me learn names faster AND it means I can call on specific students, which increases participation dramatically."

— Lecturer, Political Science

docs.title: Grading & Feedback
docs.text:
Audio Comments

"I started recording audio feedback instead of typing comments. It's faster for me, students find it more personal, and they actually listen to it. I use a simple voice memo and upload to Canvas."

— Assistant Professor, English

Comment Bank

"I built a bank of common feedback comments in a Google Doc. When grading, I copy-paste and customize. It cut my grading time by 30% and made feedback more consistent."

— Graduate Teaching Assistant, Sociology

Rubric Transparency

"I share my rubric before the assignment, then require students to self-assess using the rubric before submitting. The quality of submissions improved dramatically."

— Associate Teaching Professor, Computer Science

docs.title: Time Management
docs.text:
Batching Email

"I only answer student emails twice a day—late morning and late afternoon. I put this in my syllabus and students actually seem to appreciate the predictability. And I'm much less distracted."

— Professor, Economics

15-Minute Buffer

"I schedule a 15-minute buffer after every class in my calendar. That's when I jot notes about what worked, what didn't, and what questions came up. It saves so much time when I teach the course again."

— Clinical Professor, Nursing

docs.title: Technology
docs.text:
Canvas Home Page

"I made my Canvas home page a simple 'what to do this week' checklist with links. Students stopped asking 'where do I find...' questions."

— Instructor, Communications

QR Code Handouts

"I include QR codes on my slides that link to relevant resources. Students can scan with their phones and have the resource saved before they leave class."

— Assistant Professor, Information Science

docs.title: Common Mid-Semester Challenges
docs.text:
Students aren't reading announcements

Try the TL;DR approach: Put the most critical information in a brief bullet list at the top. Save context and details for below the fold. See our Announcements Checklist for templates.

Attendance or engagement is dropping

Mid-semester slump is real. Consider a brief anonymous survey, a class discussion about what's working, or introducing a new activity type. Our Midterm Check-In guide can help.

I'm falling behind on grading

You're not alone. Consider whether you can provide meaningful feedback faster (rubrics, audio comments), or whether some assignments could be completion-graded. Talk to colleagues about sustainable practices.

docs.title: Canvas Announcements Checklist
docs.text: Effective announcements help students stay informed, reduce repetitive questions, and build a sense of course community. Use this checklist to craft announcements that students will actually read.

docs.title: The Anatomy of an Effective Announcement
docs.text:
The TL;DR Principle

Assume students will only read the first 3 lines. Put the most critical information there.

docs.title: Structure Template
docs.text:
📌 **TL;DR:** [One sentence with the essential action/information]

---

**What you need to do:**
- [Action item 1]
- [Action item 2]

**Key dates:**
- [Date]: [What's due/happening]

**Details:**
[Additional context for students who want to read more]

docs.title: Weekly Announcement Checklist
docs.text: Use this checklist when crafting your regular weekly announcements:

docs.title: Content
docs.text:
• [ ] Lead with the most important information (TL;DR)
  • [ ] Include specific action items students need to take
  • [ ] List all due dates for the upcoming week
  • [ ] Mention any schedule changes or room changes
  • [ ] Preview what's coming in class this week
  • [ ] Link directly to assignments or resources mentioned

docs.title: Formatting
docs.text:
• [ ] Use headers and bullet points for scannability
  • [ ] Bold key dates and deadlines
  • [ ] Keep paragraphs short (2-3 sentences max)
  • [ ] Use emojis sparingly to draw attention to key items
  • [ ] Include a clear subject line that indicates the week/topic

docs.title: Timing
docs.text:
• [ ] Post at a consistent day/time each week
  • [ ] Give students enough lead time to act on the information
  • [ ] Avoid posting late at night or early morning

docs.title: Weekly Update
docs.text:
📚 Week [#] Update: [Topic]

📌 **TL;DR:** This week we're covering [topic]. [Assignment] is due [day].

---

**This Week's Schedule:**
- [Day]: [Topic/Activity]
- [Day]: [Topic/Activity]

**Due This Week:**
- [ ] [Assignment] — Due [Day, Time]
- [ ] [Reading] — Complete before [Day]

**Coming Up:**
Next week we'll begin [topic]. Start thinking about [preview].

**Office Hours:**
I'll be available [days/times]. Drop in or [schedule an appointment](link).

Questions? Reply here or email me at [email].

docs.title: Before an Exam
docs.text:
📝 [Exam Name] Information

📌 **TL;DR:** [Exam] is [Day, Date] during class time. Bring [what to bring].

---

**Exam Details:**
- **When:** [Day, Date, Time]
- **Where:** [Location — note if different from usual]
- **Format:** [Multiple choice / short answer / essay / etc.]
- **What to bring:** [Pencil, calculator, one page of notes, etc.]
- **What you can't bring:** [Phone, notes, etc.]

docs.title: Exam Preparation Checklist
docs.text: A comprehensive checklist for creating, administering, and returning exams. Whether you're giving your first exam or your hundredth, this checklist helps ensure nothing gets overlooked.

docs.title: Content Planning
docs.text:
• [ ] Review learning objectives covered since last assessment
  • [ ] Ensure questions align with what was taught and practiced
  • [ ] Include a mix of question types (if appropriate for your discipline)
  • [ ] Balance difficulty levels (some confidence-builders, some challenges)
  • [ ] Check that point values add up correctly
  • [ ] Estimate time needed; allow students adequate time

docs.title: Question Quality
docs.text:
• [ ] Write clear, unambiguous questions
  • [ ] Avoid "trick" questions or unnecessarily complex wording
  • [ ] For multiple choice: ensure all distractors are plausible
  • [ ] For short answer/essay: clarify expected length and format
  • [ ] Check for unintended clues (e.g., grammatical hints in MC questions)
  • [ ] Have a colleague or TA review if possible

docs.title: Logistics
docs.text:
• [ ] Create clear instructions at the top of the exam
  • [ ] Include point values for each question or section
  • [ ] Leave adequate space for answers (or specify separate answer sheet)
  • [ ] Number pages and include "continued on next page" prompts
  • [ ] Create a cover page with name field and honor pledge if required

docs.title: Accommodations
docs.text:
Don't forget!

Students with ARS accommodations need advance notice. Don't wait until the last minute.

  • [ ] Identify students with ARS accommodations early in the semester
  • [ ] Schedule accommodated testing with ARS (typically 5-7 days ahead)
  • [ ] Prepare alternate format exams if needed (large print, digital, etc.)
  • [ ] Communicate with students about their testing arrangements
  • [ ] Plan for how accommodated and regular exams will be administered simultaneously

docs.title: One Week Before
docs.text:
• [ ] Send announcement with exam details (date, time, location, format)
  • [ ] Clarify what materials are permitted (notes, calculator, etc.)
  • [ ] Share any review materials or practice problems
  • [ ] Hold review session or extended office hours
  • [ ] Finalize and print exam (or set up in Canvas for digital)

docs.title: Day Before
docs.text:
• [ ] Confirm room setup and any needed technology
  • [ ] Print extra copies in case of issues
  • [ ] Prepare seating chart if using assigned seating
  • [ ] If using TAs: brief them on proctoring expectations
  • [ ] Get a good night's sleep yourself!

docs.title: Before Students Arrive
docs.text:
• [ ] Arrive early to set up the room
  • [ ] Test projector/screen if displaying instructions
  • [ ] Arrange seating to minimize cheating opportunities
  • [ ] Write start time, end time, and any key info on board
  • [ ] Have blank scratch paper available if needed

docs.title: During the Exam
docs.text:
• [ ] Announce start time and how much time remains periodically
  • [ ] Walk around the room periodically (but don't hover)
  • [ ] Be available for questions but minimize disruption
  • [ ] Note any issues or questions that arise (for future reference)
  • [ ] Handle suspected academic integrity issues calmly and discreetly
  • [ ] Give 15-minute, 5-minute, and 1-minute warnings

docs.title: Collecting Exams
docs.text:
• [ ] Ensure all exams are accounted for
  • [ ] Collect any scratch paper if required
  • [ ] Keep exams secure (never leave unattended)
  • [ ] Thank students for their effort

docs.title: Grading
docs.text:
• [ ] Create or finalize rubric/answer key before grading
  • [ ] If using TAs: meet to norm grading expectations
  • [ ] Grade all responses to one question before moving to the next
  • [ ] Note common errors or misconceptions for class discussion
  • [ ] Double-check grade calculations
  • [ ] Enter grades in Canvas promptly

docs.title: Returning Exams
docs.text:
• [ ] Return exams within a reasonable timeframe (1-2 weeks)
  • [ ] Decide how to return: in class, office hours, Canvas (for digital)
  • [ ] Plan for how students can review and discuss their performance
  • [ ] Post solutions or review key points in class
  • [ ] Be prepared for grade disputes; set clear regrade policies

docs.title: Reflection
docs.text:
• [ ] Note questions that were too easy or too hard
  • [ ] Identify concepts students struggled with (reteach if needed)
  • [ ] Save data for course improvement planning
  • [ ] File exam securely for your records

docs.title: Dr. Sarah Chen on Active Learning
docs.text:
Dr. Sarah Chen Associate Professor of Economics Teaching at UNC since 2015

Courses: ECON 101 (Intro to Economics), ECON 325 (Behavioral Economics)

docs.title: "The best class sessions are the ones where I talk the least."
docs.text: Dr. Sarah Chen used to lecture for the full 75 minutes of her Introduction to Economics course. Now, she rarely talks for more than 15 minutes at a stretch—and her students are learning more than ever.

docs.title: What prompted you to change your teaching approach?
docs.text:
"I was teaching ECON 101 for the third time and noticing the same pattern: students seemed engaged during lecture, nodded along, took notes—and then bombed the first exam on the exact concepts I thought I'd explained clearly.

I kept thinking I needed to explain better. But then I read Make It Stick by Brown, Roediger, and McDaniel, and it clicked: the problem wasn't my explanations. The problem was that students weren't doing anything with the material. They were listening, but not actively processing."

docs.title: What does a typical class look like now?
docs.text:
"I break the 75 minutes into chunks. It might look like:

  • 10 minutes: Quick review quiz (ungraded, just to activate prior knowledge)
  • 15 minutes: Mini-lecture introducing the new concept
  • 20 minutes: Small group problem-solving on a realistic scenario
  • 10 minutes: Groups share solutions; I highlight common approaches and errors
  • 15 minutes: Individual practice with immediate feedback
  • 5 minutes: Muddiest point exit ticket

Not every class is exactly this formula, but the principle is the same: I talk less, they do more."

docs.title: How do students respond?
docs.text:
"At first, some students didn't love it. They'd say things like 'Why aren't you teaching us?' I had to be explicit about why I was structuring class this way—I'd share the research on active learning and explain that the discomfort of struggling with problems is actually the feeling of learning happening.

By midterm, most students had come around. And the evaluations at the end of the semester were the best I've ever had. One student wrote, 'I thought I hated econ, but I actually understand it now.'"

docs.title: What advice would you give to someone who wants to try this?
docs.text:
"Start small. You don't have to transform your entire course overnight. Pick one class session and try adding a 10-minute active learning segment. See how it goes. Iterate.

Also, prepare more than you think you need. When students are working in groups, sometimes they finish faster than expected. Have an extension activity ready.

And embrace the messiness. Active learning is noisier and less predictable than lecturing. That's okay. That's actually the point."

docs.title: Quick Tips from Dr. Chen
docs.text:
On group work

"Groups of 3-4 work best. Any larger and someone always checks out. I also assign roles: one person writes, one person manages time, one person is ready to report out."

On getting started

"Steal shamelessly. There are so many resources out there. I adapted most of my activities from things I found online or borrowed from colleagues."

On difficult concepts

"The concepts students struggle with most are exactly the ones they need to practice, not just hear about. If I know something is hard, I build in extra practice time—even if it means covering less content."

docs.title: Resources Dr. Chen Recommends
docs.text:
• Make It Stick: The Science of Successful Learning by Brown, Roediger, and McDaniel
  • Small Teaching by James Lang
  • SERC Teaching Resources — Ready-to-use active learning activities

UNC's Microsoft Copilot 365 subscription offers Teaching Tools for instructors.

You can find them in the sidebar under Teach or by following this direct link: https://m365.cloud.microsoft/teach/

UNC's Officially Supported AI Tools with FERPA Data Protection

Copilot 365 is currently only AI platform at UNC that is sanctioned for FERPA protected information education records such as student grades (Tier 2). UNC's license agreement with Microsoft Copilot 365 has support for UNC Tier 1 (Business Information) and Tier 2 (Confidential Information) data.

docs.title: Lesson Plan Creator
docs.text:
Brainstorm and iterate on a structured lesson plan by filling in a simple form with the following fields. This is a useful tool for finding new ideas for lessons that need refreshing or sanity checking a new lesson you are working on.

  • Subject
  • Grade Level: Higher Education
  • Description: Learning and content scope of the lecture (10,000 character limit)
  • Optional file attachments
  • Duration (free text customizable to 50 minutes)

The tool generates a structured document broken down into timed segments. You can edit the draft directly or enhance it with AI by changing tone, length, or providing custom instructions. You can go back to earlier drafts at any time.

When you are satisfied with a draft, in one click you an save it to your OneDrive as a Word document that is easily exported to PDF or further edited.

60-second Idea: Bring Active Learning to a Lecture

Do you have a lecture you would like to add active learning to? Try uploading your current slide deck and a simple description prompt along the lines of, "I would like to iterate on my attached lecture to meet the same learning objectives but with additional moments of active learning exercises added in. Let's brainstorm."

docs.title: Rubric Creator
docs.text:
It is common for grading to be delayed by being stuck on the "rubric block" of crafting a fair rubric for an assignment. Copilot 365's Rubric Creator can help you brainstorm a starting point for a rubric.

Step 1. Information about the Assignment

Step 2. Rubric Scale and Evaluation Criteria

Step 3. Rubric Generation

Step 4. Edit and Export

You can manually edit individual blocks, add and remove rows and columns, or further regenerate with AI. Once you are satisfied with the rubric, you can export it as a Word document to your UNC OneDrive for further editing or printing.

docs.title: MagicSchool.ai
docs.text:
Applications Cost Time to Setup Shortcut UNC Data Protection Lesson PlanningGroup WorkRubricWorksheets Free for Basic Use,$100/yr for Heavy Use 5 - 10 minutes magicschool.ai No

Magic School is a collection of AI-powered tools for educators. Each tool has simple input forms to structure the workflow, unlike AI chats where you need to detailed prompts from scratch.

There are over 50+ AI tools ("generators") tailored to specific teaching tasks. The most useful for a university setting are outlined below.

docs.title: Demonstration Video
docs.text: For a quick preview of how this platform works, this 3-minute demonstration walks you through using the rubric tool to generate a rough draft of a grading rubric for an assignment.

docs.title: Example Tools
docs.text: MagicSchool has a wide variety of focused AI tools serving university instructors through grade school. The tools below are those we beleve are relevant to Carolina faculty to help with brainstorming and drafting instructional ideas.

docs.title: Lesson Planning
docs.text: Generate a lesson plan based on a topic or learning objective and add additional criteria such as lesson length or information on pre-lecture assignments. The tool generates an editable lecture outline document with Learning Objective, Assessments (formative and summative), Key Points, and an outline of lesson structure. You are able to edit the document directly, edit your original prompt to regenerate all over again, or engage with a chat-like interface for refinements. Export to Word Document or Google Document is supported.

docs.title: Group Work Generator
docs.text:
Generate group work activity for students by describing the topic or objective, the duration of class time available, and selecting the group size. The tool will brainstorm roles and instructions for structured group work activities.

60-second Idea: Add Roles to Classroom Group Work

Assigning roles to students in group work activities in class is known to improve student learning experiences. Has coming up with roles and their instructions prevented you from trying role-based group work in the past?

Try out the Group Work tool with one of your unstructured discussion activities in class! It can help you brainstorm roles along with draft instructions for how to structure an activity.

docs.title: Rubric Generator
docs.text: Generate a custom grid-based rubric for any assignment. Specify your point scale, learning objective, assignment description (file upload, OneDrive upload, or copy/paste from Canvas are all supported), and additional customization. You can update these fields to regenerate with more specificity. For a visual demo, see the video linked above.

docs.title: Multiple Choice Quiz / Assessment
docs.text: Generate a multiple choice assessment, quiz, or test based on any topic or criteria. You provide the number of questions and description of assessment scope or upload a file, such as a PDF or word document. With a 75,000 word limit on input text, you can upload assigned academic papers or assigned readings for draft Guided Reading Questions. Answer keys are generated.

docs.title: Worksheet Generator
docs.text: Similar to the multiple choice tool, this tool generates a worksheet with fill-in-the-blank questions, multiple choice questions, and open-ended questions that can be used to brainstorm assignments. The worksheet can be edited directly as a document or you can give feedback or requested edits via a chat interface, for example "draft a few more challenging open ended questions that engage with the ethical concerns of this topic." Worksheets can be exported to Word or Google Docs.

docs.title: Cost
docs.text: MagicSchool is a commercial tool that UNC does not have a site license to. However, it is free for general usage with reasonable limits on the number of generations used per day. For unlimited generations per day, the cost is $12.99 per month or $100 per year.

docs.title: AI Tools for Teaching
docs.text:
Artificial intelligence tools are transforming how instructors prepare for class, create materials, and support student learning. This section provides practical guidance on using AI effectively and ethically in your teaching.

Evolving landscape

AI tools are developing rapidly. While we strive to keep this information current, always verify specific features and capabilities with the tools themselves.

docs.title: AI Tool Guides
docs.text:
### Reading Questions Generate engaging discussion prompts

### Office Hours Prep Anticipate student questions

docs.title: 1. AI as Assistant, Not Replacement
docs.text:
AI works best as a tool that augments your expertise, not replaces your judgment. Use it for:

  • Drafting content you'll review and refine
  • Generating options and variations
  • Handling time-consuming but routine tasks
  • Brainstorming and overcoming blocks

docs.title: 2. Review Everything
docs.text:
AI output requires human review. Always:

  • Check factual accuracy
  • Ensure alignment with your course goals
  • Verify appropriate difficulty level
  • Adapt language and examples for your students

docs.title: 3. Be Transparent
docs.text:
Consider being open with students about how you use AI:

  • Modeling appropriate use
  • Discussing ethical considerations
  • Setting clear expectations for their use of AI

docs.title: 4. Protect Privacy
docs.text:
When using AI tools:

  • Don't upload student work or data without consent
  • Use anonymized or hypothetical examples
  • Review tool privacy policies
  • Consider data storage and retention

docs.title: Generating Reading Questions with AI
docs.text:
Time savings: ~30-60 minutes per reading

Transform lengthy readings into engaging discussion questions in minutes using AI tools. This guide walks you through a repeatable process for generating high-quality reading questions.

docs.title: Video Walkthrough
docs.text:
Video placeholder

This is a placeholder for a CFE tutorial video. When the actual video is created, replace the YouTube URL above.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Generating reading questions manually is time-consuming but essential for promoting engaged reading and meaningful discussion. AI can dramatically speed up this process while still allowing you to curate and refine the final questions.

docs.title: What You'll Need
docs.text:
• Access to an AI tool (ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, etc.)
  • A PDF or text version of the reading
  • 10-15 minutes per reading

docs.title: Learning Objectives This Supports
docs.text:
• Helping students identify key arguments and themes
  • Preparing students for class discussion
  • Encouraging deeper engagement with texts
  • Building critical thinking skills

docs.title: Step 1: Prepare the Reading
docs.text:
Keep it focused

For best results, work with one article or chapter at a time rather than multiple readings.

Options for getting text into AI:

Copy/Paste TextSummarize FirstUse PDF Upload (if available)
  1. Copy the relevant text from your PDF or source
  2. Paste directly into the AI tool
  3. Works well for shorter readings (under 5,000 words)
  1. If the reading is too long, ask AI to summarize it first
  2. Then generate questions from the summary
  3. Review to ensure key concepts aren't missed
  1. Some AI tools allow PDF upload directly
  2. Upload the document
  3. Reference it in your prompt

docs.title: Step 2: Write Your Prompt
docs.text:
The quality of questions depends heavily on your prompt. Here's a template:

I'm teaching a [level] course on [subject]. Students will read the 
attached article/chapter before our class discussion.

Please generate [number] discussion questions based on this reading that:
- Move beyond simple recall to analysis and application
- Connect to [specific themes or concepts you're covering]
- Are appropriate for [undergraduate/graduate] students
- Include a mix of:
  - Questions about the author's main argument
  - Questions that ask students to evaluate evidence
  - Questions that connect to [broader course themes or current events]
  - One question that challenges students to disagree with or complicate the author's position

Format each question with a brief note about what aspect of the reading it addresses.

[Paste reading or reference uploaded document]

docs.title: Example Filled-In Prompt
docs.text:
I'm teaching an undergraduate course on Environmental Policy. Students 
will read the attached chapter on carbon pricing before our seminar.

Please generate 6 discussion questions based on this reading that:
- Move beyond simple recall to analysis and application  
- Connect to our unit on market-based environmental solutions
- Are appropriate for upper-level undergraduate students
- Include a mix of:
  - Questions about the author's main argument
  - Questions that ask students to evaluate evidence
  - Questions that connect to current climate policy debates
  - One question that challenges students to disagree with or complicate the author's position

Format each question with a brief note about what aspect of the reading it addresses.

docs.title: Step 3: Review and Refine
docs.text:
AI-generated questions are a starting point, not a finished product. Review for:

Check Questions to Ask Relevance Does this question connect to my learning objectives? Level Is this appropriate for my students' background? Clarity Will students understand what's being asked? Depth Does this go beyond what students could answer without reading? Balance Do I have a mix of question types?

docs.title: Common Refinements
docs.text:
• Simplify overly complex questions
  • Add context or scaffolding for challenging questions
  • Remove questions that miss the point
  • Adjust vocabulary for your student population
  • Add your own questions for key points AI missed

docs.title: Step 4: Format for Your Use
docs.text:
For Canvas Discussion Board:

After completing this week's reading on [topic], respond to ONE of the 
following questions in 200-300 words:

1. [Question 1]
2. [Question 2]
3. [Question 3]

Then, reply to at least one classmate's post with a substantive response.

For In-Class Discussion:

  • Choose 3-4 questions maximum
  • Order from more accessible to more challenging
  • Prepare follow-up probes for each question
  • Consider small group work before full-class discussion

For Reading Quiz:

  • Adapt open-ended questions into multiple choice or short answer
  • Focus on questions that verify engagement with the reading
  • Combine with recall questions about key facts/arguments

docs.title: Sample Output
docs.text:
Here's an example of AI-generated questions with instructor refinement:

AI-Generated Question (Original)

"How does the author's theoretical framework for understanding carbon pricing mechanisms intersect with neoliberal economic paradigms, and what are the implications for environmental justice?"

Refined Question (After Review)

"The author argues that carbon pricing can be both economically efficient and equitable. What evidence does the author provide for this claim? Do you find it convincing? Why or why not?"

docs.title: Pro Tips
docs.text:
From Dr. James Park, Political Science

"I regenerate questions multiple times and combine the best from each batch. It takes an extra few minutes but gives me much better options to choose from."

From Prof. Lisa Torres, English

"I always add one question of my own that connects to something specific we discussed in the previous class. It helps students see the through-line of the course."

docs.title: For Different Question Types
docs.text:
Bloom's Taxonomy Framing: 

Generate 2 questions at each level: remembering, understanding, 
applying, analyzing, evaluating, and creating.

Debate Preparation: 

Generate questions that could help students prepare to argue 
either for or against the author's main thesis.

Connection Questions: 

Generate questions that help students connect this reading to 
[previous reading/concept/real-world example].

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
Questions are too basic/surface-level

Revise your prompt to explicitly request higher-order thinking. Add phrases like "analysis and evaluation" and "require evidence from the text."

Questions don't match my course

Add more context about your course, students, and specific learning objectives. The more specific your prompt, the better the output.

AI didn't capture the key argument

Try explicitly summarizing what you see as the key argument and asking for questions about that specific point.
